text: [Music]
hello this is chef john from food wishes
comm with cacio e pepe taralli
that's right i'm going to show you my
first ever attempt at making trolley
which an italian translates to mini
bagel cracker pretzel or at least that's
what I assume I didn't actually look it
up but anyway that's what these
basically are and apparently there's
hundreds of different versions of these
both sweet and savory and what you're
about to see here is me trying to make a
pepper and cheese trolley so with that
let's go ahead and get started by making
a very very simple dough which will
include some all-purpose flour some salt
and a whole bunch of freshly ground
black pepper and then what we'll do is
take a spoon and give this a quick mix
before adding our wet ingredients and
there's only two we're gonna drizzle in
some extra virgin olive oil plus believe
it or not some white wine and yes it is
very very rare we do a dough where we
don't use any water but I really do
think it's the use of wine here that
gives these such an unique texture and
taste and then what we'll do once all
that's in there is take our spoon and
give this a mix until it all comes
together at which point we can go ahead
and switch to our hand and finish this
off by giving it a couple minutes of
kneading oh and by the way speaking of
taste if you were gonna flavor these
with something besides black pepper
like maybe chili flakes or fennel seed
you'd want to add that stuff in at this
step so please feel free to flavor these
any way you want
I mean you are after all this fan golly
of your trolley and you are the one in
control complete control but anyway like
I said we'll give that a mix with the
spoon and then switch to our hand and
we're gonna want to knead this for about
three or four minutes or until we have a
beautifully smooth and relatively soft
ball of dough and of course while we're
needing if it seems kind of wet and
loose we can always add a little more
flour but this one was feeling pretty
good and thanks to all the olive oil on
this felt really supple and really was a
pleasure to knead and then what we'll do
once we do have a nice smooth and soft
ball of dough is go ahead and wrap it in
plastic and we will let it sit out at
room temp for at least thirty minutes or
a longer is probably okay but at least
thirty minutes please
and turning that 30 minutes our flowers
gonna have a chance to hydrate as well
as other things are gonna happen that
science still doesn't fully understand
and then what we'll do after we've given
our dough a chance to rest let's go
ahead and unwrap it and we will divide
that into quarters and then what will
attempt to do here with each of those
pieces of dough is to roll it out using
the flats of our hands into a rope about
10 to 12 inches long and as I mentioned
when we were needing this thanks to the
oil in this it is really not that sticky
at all which is why you don't see me
sprinkle in any flour down so if you're
brand-new to working with dough this is
kind of a nice one since it really is
quite easy to work with so we'll go
ahead and roll that dough out in a four
ropes as shown which I believe Muhammad
Ali referred to is he old ropa dough and
then what we'll do is take our bench
scraper or dull knife and divide each of
these ropes in the three equal pieces
giving us 12 altogether I know thank you
mister math and then once all these are
portion we'll go ahead and roll those
out one more time to maybe like five or
six inches long which point we're going
to give them a little twist and then
form them into a ring making sure we're
sealing both of the ends together the
best we can which because it's dough is
oily is not the easiest thing to do so I
really tried to make sure I was twisting
and smearing and smashing those ends
together and by the way I don't think
that twisting is traditional it's just
something I thought would be good to do
as I was thinking it might give these a
little more of a flaky texture which
might have actually worked although
apparently once baked these are supposed
to have smooth shiny surfaces but since
I was planning on grating cheese all
over these things I didn't think it
would matter but anyway I went ahead and
rolled twisted and ringed the rest of
that dough up oh and if you do decide to
twist don't do it too much all right I
think I over twisted this last one which
thanks to our old friend gluten Mae did
not want to stay in a ring shape but
that's fine
mostly because I didn't care that much
how these came out looking which is a
very very enjoyable way to cook and then
what we'll do at this point is transfer
these four or five at a time into some
boiling water oh by the way I did add a
big pinch of salt to the water since
that just seemed like something I should
do
and as soon as you place these in
they're gonna sink right to the bottom
and just to be safe because I was using
such a shallow pan I used a spatula to
make sure these weren't sticking which
they weren't and all we need to do here
is just cook these for a couple minutes
or until they float to the surface and
as that was happening I could see I was
having a few issues all right one was
kind of losing its ring shape and
another one had a severe protrusion and
as you can see one pulled apart
completely which was unfortunate but as
you know we never let the food win and
because the dough was still kind of soft
and gummy I was able to kind of stick
those ends together and then I moved on
and went ahead and boiled the rest too
as you can see some mixed results but I
just kept telling myself relax these are
getting covered with cheese and you're
gonna tell people they're supposed to be
rustic and then speaking of cheese while
those drained on a paper towel for a
minute I went ahead and graded 12
Parmesan cheese landing pads on which to
place my boiled rings of dough and I did
this because I want to cheese under and
on top so after tossing them around in
the cheese on the Silpat I went ahead
and grated some more over the top and in
hindsight this was kind of dumb since I
probably should have just grade the
cheese on a small saucer and then coated
each one individually and then
transferred it onto the pan although if
I had done that once these were baked I
would not have been able to eat all
those little crispy bits of cheese off
the pan so all's well that ends well oh
and I should mention I'm using
parmigiano-reggiano but for a little
more authenticity cacio e pepe is
usually made with pecorino but either is
gonna work right here and then what
we'll do once those have been severely
cacio de is go ahead and transfer those
into the center of a 400 degree oven for
about 25 minutes or until lightly golden
and crunchy all the way through which by
the way you're not gonna be able to tell
until they're all the way cooled which
is something we definitely have to wait
for okay you do not want to eat these
hot or warm they need to cool to become
crunchy and as I transfer those onto
this rack you can see that about half of
them actually form this beautiful lacy
wafer of cheese in the middle which i
think is very cool okay you're gonna get
an even better look at that here
but anyway we'll go ahead and let those
cool completely before serving those up
next is some nice cold Italian white
wine and you know what for a first
attempt I thought these came out looking
pretty good alright for something like
this if you want perfect rings I'm
estimating you'd have to make two to
three thousand before you get it down
which means I'm never gonna get it down
and as far as the taste cozies are very
flavorful all right obviously because of
the pepper and cheese but also the
acidity from the white wine sort of
gives these a sourdough like effect so I
found these to be very tasty and
addictive and not just adjectives
because of the taste but also because of
their very unique crispy crunchy texture
alright the very very center is a little
less crunchy than the outside which
really does make for a very very
interesting bite oh and apparently some
people like to dunk these in the wine
which I really can't do here I either
need a bigger glass or skinnier fingers
although let me tip the glass so I can
see how this is and that was actually
surprisingly enjoyable art it was wet
but it was still crunchy and delicious
but anyway that's it my take on Tralee
alright there's an old Italian saying
that if you have enough time to make
your own mini bagel cracker pretzels you
should probably have a few more kids
which kind of makes sense but this is
not the kind of thing you spend all day
making alone alright call up some
friends and family tell them to bring
over some white wine and make a whole
bunch of all kinds of different flavors
okay so with that in mind I'll just
finish by saying I really do hope you
give these a try soon so please follow

and as always enjoy
